com.pb.sawdust.util.abacus

Class Abacus

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.util.abacus.Abacus
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.Iterator<int[]>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    LockableAbacus, LockShiftingAbacus, RollingAbacus

    public class Abacus
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.Iterator<int[]>
    The Abacus class provides an integer rolling counter (similar to an analog odometer). Abacus values are represented as arrays whose individual elements represent counters whose relative "value" increases from the last array element to the first (or the opposite, if a reverse flag has been set). Whenever an abacus is incremented, its lowest value entry is incremented by one, and if that new value exceeds the maximum for that entry, it "rolls over" - it gets set to zero and the next entry is incremented. As an example, if a three-dimensional abacus with dimensions 8,5,3 has the following position: 
         
         [0,4,2]
    then incrementing the abacus will lead to the following state: 
         
         [1,0,0]

    Abacus implements the Iterator<int[]> interface, and uses the next() method to increment. Once an abacus has "maxxed out" (reached a position where a increment would force the highest value entry to rollover) calls to next() will throw an NoSuchElementEzception; that is, an abacus will not cycle infinitely. Because there is no way to reset or decrement an abacus, it is intended for one-time use only. If a multi-use abacus is desired, the static getMultiAbacus methods will return an Iterable<int[]> whose iterator() method will use a fresh abacus each time (this object also has the advantage that it can be used in "for each" calls).

    An abacus is particularly useful for cycling through rectangular multi-dimensional arrays. For a given array with (int[]) dimensions d, an abacus created with the dimensions d will cycle through every array index position before completing.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Abacus

        public Abacus(int... dimensions)
        Constructor for a standard (non-reversed) abacus specifying its dimensions.
        Parameters:
        dimensions - The dimensions of the abacus. Each entry specifies the value at which a "rollover" occurs.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if dimensions.length == 0, or if any entry in dimensions is less than one.

      • Abacus

        public Abacus(boolean reverse,
      int... dimensions)
        Constructor specifying the dimensions of the abacus and its value precedence direction. If the reverse flag is set to false, then a "standard" abacus, where decreasing array indexes indicate increasing value precedence, will be built; if reverse is set to true, then the lower the array index, the lower the value precedence.
        Parameters:
        reverse - Flag indicating whether the value precedence should be reversed or not in the abacus.
        dimensions - The dimensions of the abacus. Each entry specifies the value at which a "rollover" occurs.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if dimensions.length == 0, or if any entry in dimensions is less than one.

    • Method Detail

      • hasNext

        public boolean hasNext()
        Indicates whether this abacus has reached its maximum value or not. If this returns false, the subsequent calls to next() will cause a NoSuchElementException to be thrown.
        Specified by:
        hasNext in interface java.util.Iterator<int[]>
        Returns:
        true if the abacus has not reached its maximum value, or false if it has.

      • next

        public int[] next()
        Increment the abacus and return the result.
        Specified by:
        next in interface java.util.Iterator<int[]>
        Returns:
        the incremented result.
        Throws:
        java.util.NoSuchElementException - if the abacus has already reached its maximum value.

      • remove

        public void remove()
        This method is not supported and throws an UnsupportedOperationException.
        Specified by:
        remove in interface java.util.Iterator<int[]>
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is called.

      • getStateCount

        public long getStateCount()
        Get the total number of unique states of this abacus. This may not be equal to the length of the abacus, in the case that the abacus returns duplicate states at different points in its iteration.
        Returns:
        the number of unique states of this abacus.

      • freshClone

        public Abacus freshClone()
        Get a new abacus with the same structure as this one set at its first positional state. This method does not affect this abacus.
        Returns:
        a new clone of this abacus with its position state set to that in which now iterations have been performed.

      • getAbacusPoint

        public int[] getAbacusPoint(long iteratorPosition)
        Get the array returned by this abacus after a given number of iterations. This method is more efficient than explicitly iterating through a fresh clone of this abacus, and thus can be useful in quickly getting a single position in this abacus's iteration cycle.
        Parameters:
        iteratorPosition - The iteration position of interest.
        Returns:
        the abacus point at iterationPosition.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if iterationPosition is less than 0 or greater or equal to the length of this abacus.

      • setAbacusAtPosition

        public void setAbacusAtPosition(long iteratorPosition)
        Set this abacus's state to that which it would have after a given number of iterations. The iterator position argument refers to the number of iterations on a fresh clone, not the current state of this abacus.
        Parameters:
        iteratorPosition - The position to set this abacus at.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if iterationPosition is less than 0 or greater or equal to the length of this abacus.

      • setAbacusPoint

        public void setAbacusPoint(int[] point)
        Set this abacus's state as if its last iteration step returned the specified element point.
        Parameters:
        point - The point to set the abacus at.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if point.length does not equal the dimensional length of this abacus, or if any value in point is less than 0 or greater than the maximum abacus value in its respective dimension.

      • getLength

        public long getLength()
        Get the total number of times this abacus can be iterated. That is, the number of times next() can be called on a fresh clone of this abacus before hasNext() returns false.
        Returns:
        the number of times this abacus can be iterated.
